default.title: tale:net - an intergalactic skill & idea sharing network

text: Get connected to a distributed network

Till now, your tale:net is empty, because you're not connected to anyone else. To synchronize your tale:net you either need to be connected via your local network to someone already using tale:net or you have to connect to a public server, a so called "pub".
Imagine a pub like a 24/7 bar - a place where people meet to update and spread out again with established connection. It's always open and the barkeeper is knowing about the latest updates.
Click get:invite to automaticly download your personal invitation for our tale:net public server. If this is done, join:pub to connect.

introduction.text: Find yellow explanation boxes like this on every page. They will guide you through tale:net. You can hide each box if you don't need it. Reset all explanation boxes at any time in my:config, where you'll also find contact information to ask for help and/or share your feedback with us.

about.welcome: Congrats! If you see the activity indicator above moving, you're synchronizing with the pub and your tale:net is filling with ideas, skills and thoughts \o/. While syncing we recommend you to have a look at our welcoming letter. It will allow you a confident use of tale:net.
text: This is a tool to free your skills and ideas. It's based on the love of doing and collaboration and it's not based on any belief in reward, competition or institutionalized expertise. "tale" is a word of a new language. It combines the meaning of sharing and helping, knowledge and skills that each of us is able to contribute. Our aim with this tool is to connect epic ideas with a desire for action - to collectively create and expand a culture of selfworth and usefulness for every1.

There are ideas, skills and identites in tale:net. You're defining skills for your identity and asking for skills on an idea, it's like "skilltagging". You can push and pull ideas. pull:ideas will always show you those ideas that ask for one or more of your skills. Pushing an idea means to send it to the tale:verse and "tag" it with skills that might be needed to realize it. Thereby, ideas are always shown to those people that have the skills and therefore knowledge to help an idea evolve and realize it. Your ideas are those you're thinking about, not necessarily those you came up with.
Two more things we want you to know:

Changing information in tale:net won't delete anything, but update the database. This is transparency. When you're, for example, changing your identities name from maria to mario, there will still be the information that you identified as maria before.

You'll not set a password for your tale:net identity, because it works with asymetric encryption. The easy way to explain this: There is a private key saved to your computer that works like a password and there is a public key visible to other people that works like a signature. If you want to be safe, you can [backup your key pair](Link save secret) to a trusted location like your usb stick, but keep it secret.
On our [website](external link website/concepts) we're providing more explanation on the concept of tale:net and {ssbLink}, which it is build on. We think it's awesome and you should know about it.

Setup your identity, define your skills and enjoy pulling ideas for the first time. Browse the skilliverse to see all skills in tale:net and get inspired. And go ahead pushing that idea you've had in mind since years...
Yours baldo, cryptix, katze, luroc & staschek (Links to identities).

introduction.text: Each identity can hold specific information: an image, a name, a description and defined skills. All this information is public and you can update it whenever you want. By defining your skills, you're influencing which ideas you'll see in pull:ideas. You don't need a name, an image or a description, but if you're not defining your skills, nothing will happen.
introduction.callToAction: Edit your identity here and keep your skills up to date in my:skills.

name.label: Name
name.placeholder: Name this identity. You never have to use your real name...
name.description: If there is no name published for this identity, it is visible with its public key.

description.label: Description
description.placeholder: Do you want to describe this identity, for example, with a mission statement or your favourite quote?

introduction.text: Instead of setting a password for an identity, your sbot creates a bunch of random secret data and saves this to your computer. Your sbot is using this random data to create a signature for information your identitiy is giving to tale:net. The asymetric kind of cryptography used here also produces a public counterpart of the secret data, which is displayed on every identity. Sbots use this public data to verify the signature of other identitie's information, which means that they can't cheat each other when exchanging information.
introduction.callToAction: If you lose your secret data you won't be able to access your identity any more, it's a good idea to backup your key:file in a trusted location.

introduction.text: Define your skills to pull matching ideas from tale:net. Think beyond any concept of work or labor. Think of whatever you're dedicated to do, really good at or always enjoy spending your time on. You're certainly good in things, you might have not defined as a skill yet, because it seems very normal to you. If you start typing the name of a skill, you will see similar skills that were already added to tale:net. All skills added to tale:net are collected and connected in the skilliverse [under construction]. The similarity of skills is actively set and maintained by all identiites in the skilliverse.
introduction.callToAction: Define your skills. Don't hesitate to choose more than one - The more skills you're defining the more ideas will match. Please check the existing skills before adding a new one to the skilliverse.

selectSkill.label: Define a skill for this identity

selectSkill.description: As soon as you start typing you will see similar skills that exist in the skilliverse. You can either choose an existing skill or add a new one to the skilliverse, if you think it needs to be added.

introduction.text: Set a connection to vote a similarity or a general relation between 2 skills. These connections influence the type ahead skill proposals and the matching of ideas [under construction]. By doubling an already existing connection you're enhancing the similarity with your vote.
introduction.callToAction: Don't hesitate. The skilliverse is shaped constantly by all identities.

introduction.text: Ideas can be short brainstorms, problems to solve, questions to answer or detailled plans. Set a title for an idea, add a description and ask for skills that might be needed to realize it or help it evolve.  When publishing 1 idea, you'll hold the hat by default. This means to hold the responsability to update an idea and initialize its realization. If you drop:hat and un:think this idea after publishing, it woun't be shown to you unless you have matching skills.
introduction.callToAction: Each perspective is unique, all ideas you have in mind are worth sharing.

description.label: Description
description.placeholder: What's the vision, question, plan...? Share all details to enable reasonable follow-up thinking and making. Ask language skills for translation.

selectSkill.placeholder: Which skills might be needed to help this evolve?
selectSkill.description: Start typing to see existing skills and proposals that are voted as similar in the skilliverse. You can ask for existing skills or add a new one, meaning that no identitiy holds this skill yet and you're defining a need for it in tale:net.

introduction.text: There are three ways identities are related to ideas: thinking about an idea means it's your idea, you'll see and help it evolve through sharing your thoughts and knowledge. If you commit your skills [under construction], you're joining the team that takes action on an idea. If you grab the hat, you're moderating that idea. You might update the description with useful thoughts or decide on the size of a team by answering skill commitments [under construction]. The hat may also start to organize cocreation or initiate a first gathering.
introduction.callToAction: In a later version of tale:net there will be geo:location for skills and ideas [under construction]. copy:idea to restart things in your own city.

introduction.text: Find a description, asked skills and thoughts other identities shared on this idea below. If an identity is holding the hat, you can see this in skill commitments. think:about this idea to share your thoughts and knowledge. If the hat is vacant you can grab:hat. To join the evolving team around an idea commit:skills [under construction]. You can always drop the hat, take back a given skill commitment or un:think ideas. copy:idea to restart an idea that seeks to be done more than once.
introduction.callToAction: Find all ideas you're thinking about in my:ideas. Collaborate.
